newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Serbian student protestors win more backing.
newsitem.headline: Serbian student protestors win more backing.

text.p: Belgrade students, protesting for eight weeks against election fraud, scored a victory on Monday when senior academics, led by a prominent ruling socialist, backed protests against election fraud.

The Belgrade University governing board "supports the students' demands accepted by the Serbian deputy prime ministers and urges fulfillment of the commitments undertaken by them," Rector Dragutin Velickovic said.
He was speaking to reporters after a session of the board which comprises deans from all Belgrade University colleges.
The opposition Zajedno coalition claims it won 14 of Serbia's 18 largest cities, including the capital Belgrade, in November 17 local elections. International observors have backed their stand
The cancellation of the victories by the ruling Socialists, who claimed unspecified irregularities, triggered a continuing wave of daily street protests by Belgrade students and Zajedno supporters.
The highly imaginative, peaceful mass protests, echoed recently in neighbouring Bulgaria, have turned into the most serious challenge to leftist rule in Serbia since 1945.
Two Serbian deputy prime ministers agreed on Saturday to student demands for recognition of opposition election victories, access to state media, and Velickovic's dismissal.
Deputy prime ministers Ratko Markovic and Nedeljko Sipovac also told the students that those who rigged elections would be punished and they criticised state media as incompetent.
Velickovic, a Socialist Party (SPS) appointee, was against the student protest, pitting himself against most of the deans.
The board did not discuss Velickovic's sacking but referred a decision to the University Teachers Council which meets on Wednesday.
Political sources said his dismissal was highly likely, as the easiest student demand for the SPS to fulfil.
The board said "students will not bear any consequences for taking part in the protests but must return to classes once their demands were fulfilled."

Senior political sources suggested President Slobodan Milosevic and his ruling SPS and allied neo-communist Yugoslav United Left party, under immense pressure from outside and inside the country, might accept all demands to save face.
"The students are giving them a way out. They will not appear to be succumbing to the opposition which has identical demands except for the (sacking of the) rector," he said.
